newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan welcomes continued U.S. arms sales.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan welcomes continued U.S. arms sales.

text.p: Taiwan, which fired two U.S. Hawk missiles in the Taiwan Strait on Tuesday in a test seen as bolstering defences against rival China, said it welcomed continued arms sales from the United States.

"Normally, we would not comment on any ongoing arms deal, but for any deal which can help increase our defence needs or maintain peace and stability in a region, we are pleased to have it struck," said military spokesman Kung Fan-ting.

Kung declined comment on Taiwan media reports that the United States had agreed to sell 54 AGM-84A Harpoon missiles and 21 Super Cobra attack helicopters to Taiwan, a deal that would be certain to anger China.

The latest agreement was made during a meeting between Taiwan and the United States in mid-March to review Taiwan's defence needs in the face of increased Chinese military intimidation against Taiwan, local newspapers said.
Despite the absence of diplomatic relations, the United States and Taiwan hold regular meetings to review Taiwan's purchases of U.S. arms.
Beijing, which has regarded the island as a renegade province since a civil war spilt them in 1949, has repeatedly warned the United States against selling arms to Taiwan.
Washington insisted that the arms it sold to Taiwan were merely defensive.
The short-range, ground-to-air Hawk missiles Taiwan fired on Tuesday were a third-generation version the island began installing in 1995.
Military officers said Taiwan was a pioneer in deploying the latest version of Hawks and U.S. officials were on hand to see the missiles successfully destroy two target planes.
